Colin Green wrote:

>In fact a recent news story (probably 
>based on some scientific research/report) raised the issue of mixed race 
>couple's children being less susceptible to genetic diseases, because 
>the chance of aquiring the same bad gene (which are often a feature of a 
>specific race) from both parents is greatly diminished. Just a thought.
>
>  
>
Was just thinking about this point and about dominant and recessive 
genes. I'm wondering if maybe we could incorporate this type of idea 
into our artificial genomes. So the offspring of two parents contains a 
mix of genes from both, some of which may clash either directly, e.g. 
matching innovation ID's, or indirectly e.g. some sub-network is 
irrelevent in the resence of some other sub-network.  NEAT of course 
matched innovation ID's at during crossover and therefore only select a 
gene from one of the parents (usually the fittest), but the scheme could 
be expanded s that the presence of a gene automatically swicthes of one 
or more other genes at decode/transcribe time.  It's just a thought.

Colin.
